question.body: When would you conclude that the data provide enough evidence that the proportion of U.S. adults who oppose gay marriage is 50%?

multiple_choice.choice: when the p-value is small (less than .05)
when the p-value is not small (above .05)
when exactly half the individuals in the sample oppose gay marriage and half support it

part.hint: Recall that our conclusion is based on how small the p-value is. Here we're using a .05 significance level, which means that if the p-value is less than .05, we reject the null hypothesis Ho and accept the alternative hypothesis Ha.
The question here asks when we would accept the null hypothesis (that 50% of U.S. adults oppose gay marriage). Under what circumstance would we accept the null hypothesis?
We never accept the null hypothesis. The data may not provide enough evidence to accept the alternative, but that does not mean that we have evidence to accept the null.
